description: The Education Loan Scheme under the National Scheduled Castes Finance and Development Corporation (NSFDC) in Haryana provides financial assistance to Scheduled Caste (SC) students for pursuing professional or technical education at graduate and higher levels. The scheme aims to empower SC students by offering loans at concessional rates to support their educational aspirations.
key_features: Concessional interest rates for SC students
Covers professional and technical courses in India and abroad
Implemented through Haryana Scheduled Castes Finance and Development Corporation
Flexible repayment terms with moratorium period

benefits.maximum_loan_amount: Up to Rs. 20 Lakhs for studies in India; Up to Rs. 30 Lakhs for studies abroad
benefits.interest_rate: 4% per annum for male students, 3.5% per annum for female students
benefits.moratorium_period: 6 months after course completion or securing a job

education_criteria: Students pursuing professional or technical courses at graduate or postgraduate level
Courses must be recognized by UGC, AICTE, or equivalent
additional_criteria: Applicant must belong to Scheduled Castes (SC) as per Haryana government norms
Annual family income must not exceed Rs. 3 Lakhs
Must be a resident of Haryana
eligibility.admission_requirement: Admission to recognized institutions through merit or entrance tests
institution_criteria: Recognized institutions in India or abroad

eligible_courses_delhi: Engineering, medical, law, management, and other professional courses
Technical courses approved by regulatory bodies

steps: Obtain application form from Haryana Scheduled Castes Finance and Development Corporation
Fill and submit the form with required documents
Verification and sanction by the corporation
application_process.note: Contact the corporation office for application details

required_documents.note: To prove family income below Rs. 3 Lakhs

special_notes: Loan covers tuition fees, books, and living expenses
Female students receive a 0.5% interest rate concession
Repayment terms extend up to 15 years post-moratorium
